vulnerability_information:
**Summary:**
The function "**Download as CSV**" might leak information to 3rd domains. The exploitation seems unlikely and purely theoretical but it might work in some cases. 

**Description (Include Impact):**
Take downloading payments as CSV, for example, which is recently launched. The response to 
https://hackerone.com/settings/bounties.csv
returns CSV which is indeed, a comma separated values. There is a field which is influenced by user input i.e. report_title.
And, as we all know, `script` inclusions are exempt from SOP. So, if the returned CSV forms valid JavaScript, it's possible that we can read information.

### Steps To Reproduce
For demonstration;
I created an HTML page as follows;
```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <meta charset='utf-8'/>
    <script>
        var report_id,report_title,program_name,total_amount,amount,bonus_amount,currency,awarded_at,status;
    </script>
  </head>
  <body>
    <script src='https://hackerone.com/settings/bounties.csv'></script>
  </body>
</html>
```

And, edited returned response (using BurpSuite) as follows;
```JavaScript
report_id,report_title,program_name,total_amount,amount,bonus_amount,currency,awarded_at,status
████████
████
█████████
████████
██████
████████
```

So, what I did is added ```=` ```  right after first word of first report. Similarly added ``` `//``` right after last word of last report.
This makes it a valid JavaScript, and `XSS` a valid variable which now have all details in it. 

### Optional: Your Environment (Browser version, Device, etc)
Firefox version 45.7.0
UA:  Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:45.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/45.0
Safari may also work.
title: Information leakage via CSV when content is valid JavaScript

activities.markdown_message:
I've made a working POC, but highly customized to my requirements :P

You should change script src URL to;
https://hackerone.com/reports/207275/export/raw?include_internal_activities=true

I assume the report is visible to you. If not, it wont' work :(
Then open the document in Firefox or Safari, and when finished loading open your browser's console and type in;
duplicate;

activities.message:
Hey @mikkocarreon,

This sounds interesting - could you please submit a test report on our programme as a PoC so we can see this in action (with step by step instructions and successful reading of data from the foreign domain?). Please mention I asked you to do this and do not normally use @security for test reports. We do not have access to other programmes data.

Cheers!

activities.message:
Hi asuka,
I've filed a demo report which is https://hackerone.com/reports/207802

For demo, you can just visit;
http://request.rootme.in/h1csv.html


I've set the param `include_internal_activities` to `false` so that it doesn't result in **Unauthorized**.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi asuka,
I've filed a demo report which is https://hackerone.com/reports/207802

For demo, you can just visit;
http://request.rootme.in/h1csv.html

I've set the param include_internal_activities to false so that it doesn't result in Unauthorized.

In case you want a quick fix;
- Switch to POST method

It's, imo, is best preventive measure. Since this isn't a state changing action, you don't necessarily require an anti-csrf token.

activities.message: I do not see the report leaked, just a blank page. It looked like the inclusion was blocked due to a MIME-type mismatch as well. Could you please verify this again and provide step-by-step instructions?
activities.markdown_message: I do not see the report leaked, just a blank page. It looked like the inclusion was blocked due to a MIME-type mismatch as well. Could you please verify this again and provide step-by-step instructions?

activities.message:
Hi asuka,

According to MDN, Safari doesn't support `X-Content-Type-Options`. So, imo, it should work in Safari.
However, you can download and use an older version of Firefox, before 50.

I've already included browser I've tested it on. Your best bet, I think, is to use an older version of Firefox. I'll check it myself with Safari, and will let you know.
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message:
Hi @asuka,
Apologies for delay here. Safari for Windows is too old while only versions above 9 support Template literals as said in MDN.
I hope you're able to reproduce it. Let me know if you have any questions.
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message:
Hey,
I've confirmed that it works in latest versions of Safari. And, in case, you haven't been able to reproduce the issue, I've prepared a video POC;
https://youtu.be/TTBSjALrtX8
You can download previous versions of Firefox from https://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/firefox/releases/.

Regards,
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @jjoos

activities.message:
Hi @jjoos 
My apologies, I didn't notice the changes in bounties.csv. There are, however, other places where one can download CSV directly via simple GET request. For example;
view-source:https://hackerone.com/dashboard/raw.csv?end=2017-04-14&start=2017-01-14&interval=week
There may be other I'm unaware of. Though, they may not present any security risks at the moment, future changes in JavaScript or ECMAScript may allow reading such. So, please review it thoroughly.

Apart from CSV one, I've also covered raw reports which aren't CSV. Not only CSV but anything that forms valid JavaScript can be leaked crossdomain if it responds to normal GET requests. The POC I've attached shows exactly the same. I'm being able to read reports crossdomain.
I only saw changes in bounties.csv whereas others are untouched. I can still read reports crossdomain as I've already demonstrated. Please let me know if I'm missing something.
Regards,

activities.message:
I don't see any user controlled input in the link (the dashboard one) you provided and since this isn't working anymore in newer browser version I don't think it makes sense to change this to all of these url's.

> I only saw changes in bounties.csv whereas others are untouched.
What other urls did you mean, the raw report one? I don't see any realistic exploitation scenario since a report needs to be in a very specific format and that implies the attacker already has control over it.

Are there any other url's that have a realistic attack scenario?

activities.message:
Hi @jjoos,

> What other urls did you mean, the raw report one? I don't see any realistic exploitation scenario since a report needs to be in a very specific format and that implies the attacker already has control over it.

I agree but if we look back, bounties.csv also didn't have any realistic attack scenario. And, who knows, future changes in JavaScript may allow reading such. 

I believe it's trivial to remediate the issue, so why not? Anyway, it's up to your decision.

activities.message:
One possible realistic attack scenario I could think of is-
\- a user can leak internal members' comments on his/her report

For example, a user can submit report such that its title ultimately forms a valid JavaScript statement. So, later when the report is closed or whatever, s/he can ask to visit a link where s/he exploits the vulnerability being described. This will disclose internal comments, if any, to reporter. 

This seems practical as user only has to add a backtick in report's title and later close it accordingly. I hope that makes sense.
activities.markdown_message:

This seems practical as user only has to add a backtick in report's title and later close it accordingly. I hope that makes sense.

activities.message:
> I agree but if we look back, bounties.csv also didn't have any realistic attack scenario. And, who knows, future changes in JavaScript may allow reading such.

Well you provided one, also as browsers (since this isn't exploitable on the most modern browsers) will become more secure this type of issues will become less important.

> This seems practical as user only has to add a backtick in report's title and later close it accordingly. I hope that makes sense.

Agree that one could still be fixed, I'll create an internal task for it and re-open this report, thank you!

activities.message:
Thanks, @mikkocarreon, for the report, including the great POC.

As this only affects old browser versions, we're awarding our minimum bounty, plus an added extra bounty for the POC.

Happy hacking!
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks, @mikkocarreon, for the report, including the great POC.

As this only affects old browser versions, we're awarding our minimum bounty, plus an added extra bounty for the POC.

activities.message: I know you preferred not to disclose this report, but our policy is that we publicly disclose all our resolved issues. Please feel free to publish your blog post and update your summary to point to it, though.
activities.markdown_message: I know you preferred not to disclose this report, but our policy is that we publicly disclose all our resolved issues. Please feel free to publish your blog post and update your summary to point to it, though.

activities.message:
> As this only affects old browser versions, we're awarding our minimum bounty

[Here](https://hackerone.com/reports/207266#activity-1531513), I had confirmed that it worked in latest versions of Safari which, I believe, is the most used browser by HackerOne community. Safari still doesn't support `X-Content-Type-Options`. So, I wouldn't say it required older browser versions.

Anyway, could you please redact my bounties details from initial report? And, I guess, you should also change report title.

vulnerability_information_html:
Summary:
The function "Download as CSV" might leak information to 3rd domains. The exploitation seems unlikely and purely theoretical but it might work in some cases.

Description (Include Impact):
Take downloading payments as CSV, for example, which is recently launched. The response to
https://hackerone.com/settings/bounties.csv
returns CSV which is indeed, a comma separated values. There is a field which is influenced by user input i.e. report_title.
And, as we all know, script inclusions are exempt from SOP. So, if the returned CSV forms valid JavaScript, it's possible that we can read information.

Steps To Reproduce

For demonstration;
I created an HTML page as follows;

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <meta charset='utf-8'/>
    <script>
        var report_id,report_title,program_name,total_amount,amount,bonus_amount,currency,awarded_at,status;
    </script>
  </head>
  <body>
    <script src='https://hackerone.com/settings/bounties.csv'></script>
  </body>
</html>

And, edited returned response (using BurpSuite) as follows;

report_id,report_title,program_name,total_amount,amount,bonus_amount,currency,awarded_at,status
████████
████
█████████
████████
██████
████████

So, what I did is added =` right after first word of first report. Similarly added `// right after last word of last report.
This makes it a valid JavaScript, and XSS a valid variable which now have all details in it.

Optional: Your Environment (Browser version, Device, etc)

Firefox version 45.7.0
UA: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:45.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/45.0
Safari may also work.
